title: Shanklin Walks - Sandown to Shanklin Walk

images.title: Alan Swain / Promenade - Sandown - Isle of Wight
images.caption: Promenade - Sandown. View of the promenade at Sandown facing towards the pier.

images.title: Ronald Saunders from Warrington, UK, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cliff Edge Path. Part of the coastal footpath that goes between Sandown and Shanklin. A drop of a couple of hundred feet here. Not for those with vertigo.

images.caption: Old Shanklin. A quiet moment in Old Shanklin when only one car is seen passing Pencil Cottage and the Old Thatch Tearoom.

images.caption: Shanklin Beach. Beach view on a fine summer evening.

images.title: Christine Matthews / Clifftop, Shanklin
images.caption: Clifftop, Shanklin. Looking down the pathway from Keats Green to Shanklin beach. Culver Cliff can be seen on the horizon.

images.title: Peter Trimming / Shanklin Village
images.caption: Shanklin Village. Thatched homes including the Crab Inn.

description: Shanklin is a popular tourist village located on the southern part of the island. With a sandy beach, charming old village, cliff tops trails and a wooded chine it's a popular place for starting or ending a walk. This walk takes you from Sandown to Shanklin using a section of the Isle of Wight Coast Path . The walk starts in Sandown next to the pier where you can pick up the waymarked footpath and follow it south along Sandown Bay to Welcome Beach, Little Stairs Point, Hope Beach and Shanklin. It's about 2 miles on a fairly flat path so should take about an hour. There are some climbs on the way with nice views from the cliff tops sections. The route finishes near Shanklin Chine where you can enjoy a stroll through a pleasant wooded area up to the old village. Here you'll find a number of attractive old thatched buildings and a decent tourist information centre. There's also a number of fine cafes and quaint gift shops to explore here.
